newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soybeans end up, July rallies on supply.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soybeans end up, July rallies on supply.

text.p: Lingering concerns over low U.S. soybean stocks boosted July soybeans to sharply higher closes Friday, and other months ended with modest gains, traders and analysts said.

"It's still tight, there's no question about that," said Sid Love, analyst with Kropf and Love Consulting in Overland Park, Kan. "If the USDA hadn't raised (U.S.) imports, the carryout would have been 115 (million) bushels."
On Thursday, the U.S. Department of Agriculture raised 1996/97 soybean ending stocks by five million bushels to 130, but supplies are still near 20-year lows.
Around midsession, the tight supplies caused July soybeans to rally to the daily 30-cent trading limit, but the contract's inability to hold that level spurred sales, traders said.
"As soon as we failed to lock limit in July, the bulls began liquidating," said one floor trader.
In early trading, July also punctured several key resistance points, which triggered heavy buy-stop orders and accelerated the pace of gains, traders said.
July soybeans ended up 13 cents at $8.54-1/2, with other months up two to 6-1/4 cents.
Weekly crushing data from the National Oilseed Processors Association was also viewed as supportive to nearby contracts, traders said.
The NOPA crush of 25.387 million bushels came in near the high end of trade expectations and implied robust near-term demand for soybeans, traders said.
Volatile trade in the July/November spread was also noted.
On the day, Refco bought four million bushels July, Merrill Lynch bought 2.5 million July and 1.5 million November. Term Commodities sold 2.5 million July, pit sources said.

In options trade, Lind-Waldock bought 500 November $6.25 puts and sold 500 September $8.25 calls. Rosenthal bought 1,000 July $9.00 calls and Continental Grain bought 600 August $8.00 calls and sold 600 August $8.75 calls.
Soybean futures volume was estimated by the CBOT at 72,000 contracts, above Thursday's actual volume of 61,952, according to CBOT data.
